group_works.title: I am what I know
group_works.creator_credit: Glenda Fillinger, Paul Fillinger and Churchill Films

results.title: I am what I know
results.creator_credit: Glenda Fillinger, Paul Fillinger and Churchill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Feelings”.
Encourages a positive attitude towards what we do know and towards attaining new knowledge. Children’s comments and songs are used to explain that different people know different things. Illustrates ways to feel better about one’s attainments. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: I am how I look
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Feelings”.
Explores how children view their physical selves and how that relates to the whole self-image. Includes children describing how they look, the importance of differences for helping one develop a sense of self-identity and specific suggestions for liking oneself better. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: I am how I feel
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Feelings”.
One of a series of three films dealing with the question “Who am I?”. Presents a series of sketches about the expression of feelings. Ways of handling negative feelings and achieving more positive feelings are shown. All people have the same basic emotions but respond differently in particular situations. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: I'm feeling happy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Feelings”.
Children sing about and experience a number of things that bring happiness: The pleasures of smelling and eating good things, a bubbly bath, waking up on a sunny morning; the accomplishment of learning to drive, the inner satisfaction of being helpful without thought of reward and the warmth of sharing a friendship.

group_works.title: Theater of the absurd: Luigi Pirandello: Six characters in search of an author
group_works.creator_credit: Ken Frankel, Harold Mantell and Films for the Humanities

results.title: Theater of the absurd: Luigi Pirandello: Six characters in search of an author
results.creator_credit: Ken Frankel, Harold Mantell and Films for the Humanities
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the drama”.
An abridged presentation in English of Pirandello’s play in which six characters seek to exchange their fixed, frozen form in art for the uncertainty of life, to distinguish between dramatic reality and dramatic illusion, between acting and artifice in real life, and between reality and truth. Narrated by Joseph Heller.
results.title_for_label: Theater of the absurd: Luigi Pirandello: Six characters in search of an author
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Frankel, Harold Mantell and Films for the Humanities

results.title: The Monsoon frog (A)
results.creator_credit: Robin James and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Dreamtime story”.
A young boy, learning to hunt is told never to harm the green frog. In answer to his question why, he is told the story of a young boy of the Dreamtime who had no respect for nature. When the monsoon did not come one year he threatened to kill the green frog, bringer of the monsoon, if she did not send the rain. In revenge she sent her children, thunder and lightning to kill him, but he meets with Tiddalik the giant frog, which causes further complications … Narrated by Belzah Lowah.

results.title: Pariki and the flying foxes (A)
results.creator_credit: Robin James and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Dreamtime story”.
Belzah Lowah narrates this story of the Dreamtime, based on a retelling by Charles P. Mountford. The story is of Pariki, a young boy, one of the first people, who lived on an island. Although he had many animal friends he was lonely, and so, when one day he found himself in an unexplored part of the island, he ventured deep into the forest in spite of the warnings of the rock python. Here he met the evil bat spirit, whose bats caught him and carried him up into the heavens where they became stars and Pariki became the biggest star of all, with the bat spirit becoming the man in the moon.
